metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax and Income-tax Officer v. Bhagwandas Kevaldas

facts.text: The 1st Income-tax Officer, C-II Ward, Bombay, served a notice under section 18A(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, calling upon Bhagwandas Kevaldas (assessee) to pay in four equal installments Rs. 25,973-5-0 as advance tax for the assessment year 1948-49.
On September 17, 1947, the assessee filed an estimate of his income under section 18A(2) and of the tax payable by him.
On January 10, 1948, the assessee filed a revised estimate.
An order under section 23B of the Act provisionally assessing the income was made by the Income-tax Officer and pursuant thereto on August 23, 1950, the assessee paid the tax so assessed.

Regular assessment of the income was made on March 31, 1953, by the Income-tax Officer, and it was found that the tax paid on the basis of the estimate of the assessee was less than eighty per cent of tax determined as a result of the regular assessment. But the Income-tax Officer did not charge interest under sub-section (6) of S. 18A.
The departmental auditor raised an objection in auditing accounts of C-II Ward that a mistake was committed by the Income-tax Officer in failing to charge interest.

On September 21, 1956, the Income-tax Officer served a notice upon the assessee requiring him to show cause why the mistake in not levying interest be not rectified and why he should not be directed to pay penal interest under section 18A(6).

On October 4, 1956, the Income-tax Officer recorded an order: 'During the internal checking of C-II Ward, the auditor has pointed out a mistake is apparent from record the same is rectified under section 35 after giving due notice to the assessee.' and served a notice of demand calling upon the assessee to pay Rs. 14,929-10-0 as interest due under section 18A(6) for the period January 1, 1948, to July 22, 1950.

In exercise of his powers under section 33A, by order dated February 1, 1958, the Commissioner of Income-tax confirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer rectifying the original order of assessment and imposing liability to pay interest, subject to the modification that interest be paid only till June 13, 1950.

The assessee moved the High Court of Judicature at Bombay by a petition under article 226 of the Constitution for issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the orders passed under section 33A by the Commissioner and under section 35 by the Income-tax Officer and the notice of demand.
The High Court of Bombay, following its earlier judgment in Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. Nair, directed that the orders passed by the Income-tax Officer and by the Commissioner be quashed.
Against the order passed by the High Court the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Income-tax Officer appealed to the Supreme Court with certificate granted by the High Court.
Facts in Civil Appeal No. 1004 of 1963 are substantially the same as in Civil Appeal No. 1003 of 1963.

legal_issues.text: Whether a proceeding under Article 226 of the Constitution challenging levy of tax is a 'civil proceeding' within the meaning of Article 133(1) allowing the High Court to grant a certificate of appeal to the Supreme Court.

Whether the Income-tax Officer could rectify the assessment order under section 35 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, to charge interest under section 18A(6) after the retrospective amendment by Act 25 of 1953 introducing a proviso allowing discretion to reduce or waive interest, given that no interest was charged in the original regular assessment of March 31, 1953.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal is competent as the writ proceeding under Article 226 is a civil proceeding for Article 133 certificate.

Rectification under section 35 was valid as omission to charge interest was a mistake apparent from the record; retrospective proviso to section 18A(6) did not imply exercise of discretion by ITO at time of assessment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 18A(6), 35 of Income-tax Act, 1922; Act 25 of 1953; Rule 48

petitioner_arguments.text: Proviso to section 18A(6) could not be effective until rules framed in December 1953 prescribing cases for discretion.

respondent_arguments.text: Writ petition under Article 226 is not a civil proceeding; appeal incompetent under Article 133.

Even if appealable, no mistake apparent from record for rectification under section 35 due to retrospective proviso to section 18A(6) deeming discretion existed at assessment time; omission implies waiver.

court_reasoning.text: A proceeding under Article 226 seeking relief against infringement of civil rights by revenue authorities is a civil proceeding within Article 133; revenue proceedings asserting civil rights against unlawful tax levy qualify as civil.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Character depends on nature of right violated and relief claimed, not tribunal; taxation affects civil rights of taxpayer.

court_reasoning.text: Preliminary objection to appealability fails; writ proceedings can be civil if enforcing civil rights against tax levy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No warrant to exclude revenue matters from civil proceedings under Article 133.

court_reasoning.text: By retrospective amendment from April 1, 1952 via Act 25 of 1953, proviso to section 18A(6) and Rule 48 deemed in force at assessment date (March 31, 1953); ITO had discretion to waive interest; omission to charge implies exercise of discretion, no mistake apparent for section 35 rectification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legal fiction requires assuming proviso existed; failure to charge interest deemed waiver.

court_reasoning.text: Commissioner erred in assuming no retrospective effect and rejecting claim without considering proviso and Rule 48.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court right to quash for failure to consider applicable discretion.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent by Mudholkar J.: Omission was oversight, not exercise of discretion; rectification under section 35 valid as mistake apparent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence ITO purported to exercise non-existent discretion at time.

holdings.text: Proceeding under Article 226 challenging tax levy is a civil proceeding for Article 133 certificate.
ITO could not rectify under section 35 as retrospective proviso deemed discretion exercised by omission to charge interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. Nair, IV Income-tax Officer, E Ward Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay High Court followed this to quash orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessee relied; court distinguished as no absolute power existed without rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. K. Venkatachalam v. Bombay Dyeing and Manufacturing Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: ITO can rectify mistake from retrospective amendment under section 35.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Pandurang Vinayak
precedents_cited.relevance: On effect of retrospective deeming provisions.

precedents_cited.case_name: East End Dwellings Co. Ltd. v. Finsbury Borough Council
Rangoon Botatoung Co. Ltd. v. The Collector, Rangoon
precedents_cited.relevance: Land acquisition award as arbitration, needing special appeal provision.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Advance tax estimates, provisional assessment, interest for underestimation, rectification of mistakes, revision by Commissioner.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Amendment Act, 25 of 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Added discretion to reduce/waive interest retrospectively from April 1, 1952.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction; appeals from High Court judgments in civil/criminal/other proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribed cases/circumstances for reducing/waiving interest under proviso to 18A(6).

outcome.summary: Appeals by Revenue against Bombay High Court order quashing rectification of assessment and demand of interest under section 18A(6) dismissed by majority (Shah J., Mudholkar J. dissenting on merits); High Court orders upheld as writ proceeding is civil for Article 133 and no rectifiable mistake due to retrospective discretion.
outcome.relief_granted: Orders of ITO under s.35 and Commissioner under s.33A quashed; appellants to pay costs.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs; one hearing fee for both appeals.

key_quotes.text: "The expression 'civil proceeding' covers all proceedings in which a party asserts the existence of a civil right conferred by the civil law or by statute, and claims relief for breach thereof."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'civil proceeding' under Article 133 including tax challenges.

key_quotes.text: "By operation of the deeming provision, which was retrospective in its operation, it was to be assumed and taken that on the date on which he made the assessment order he had jurisdiction and power to reduce or waive the amount of interest payable by the assessee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court reasoning on retrospective effect upheld by majority.

key_quotes.text: "An omission to do what he was bound by law to do the Income-tax Officer committed an error and that error appears on the face of the record."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mudholkar J.'s dissent on why omission was rectifiable mistake.
